Title.evidence: This was a parallel group, randomized, noninferiority clinical trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: This was a parallel group, randomized, noninferiority clinical trial.

Participants.evidence: Patients with grade III/IV hemorrhoids between August 2011 and November 2013 were included.

Intervention.evidence: Three hundred patients were randomly assigned to undergo either partial stapled hemorrhoidopexy (group 1, n = 150) or circumferential stapled hemorrhoidopexy (group 2, n = 150).

Objective.evidence: The purpose of this study was to compare the long-term clinical efficacy and safety of partial stapled hemorrhoidopexy with circumferential stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of recurrent prolapse at a median follow-up period of 5 years with a predefined noninferiority margin of 3.75%.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Three hundred patients were randomly assigned to undergo either partial stapled hemorrhoidopexy (group 1, n = 150) or circumferential stapled hemorrhoidopexy (group 2, n = 150).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 5-year cumulative recurrence rate between group 1 (9% (95% CI, 4%–13%)) and group 2 (12% (95% CI, 7%–17%)) did not differ significantly ( p = 0.137), and the difference was within the noninferiority margin (absolute difference, –3.33% (95% CI, –10.00% to 3.55%)).

Harms.evidence: Postoperative rectal stenosis did not develop in patients in group 1, although it occurred in 8 patients (5%) in group 2 ( p = 0.004).
